lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
* A Deadlines object is a task with a deadline represented by a description and a date.
* Initializes a new instance of the Deadlines class with a given description and date.
* @throws DukeException if the provided description or date is null or empty.
public Deadlines(String description, String date) throws DukeException {
throw new DukeException("description of deadline cannot be empty");
throw new DukeException("date of deadline cannot be empty");
* Gets the date of the deadline.
* Gets the type of the task.
* @return A string representing the type of the task. For Deadlines, it returns "D".
* Gets a formatted string representation of the Deadlines task.
* @return A string representing the Deadlines task, including its type, completion status, description, and date.
* The main  method for the Duke application.
* It initializes the task list and listens for user commands,
* handling them appropriately based on their type.
* Determines type of command entered by the user.
* @param userCommand The command string entered by the user.
* Generates a message showing number of tasks in the list.
* @param numTasks The number of tasks currently in the list.
return "Now you have " + numTasks + " task(s) in the list";
* Handles cases when the user provides an unrecognized command.
* Outputs an error message to inform the user that the command is unknown.
* Displays the list of tasks to the user.
* @param tasks A list of tasks to be displayed.
* Each task is enumerated starting from 1 and printed using its string representation.
System.out.println("here are the tasks in your list:");
* Handles the deletion of a task from the list based on the user command.
* @param userCommand The command given by the user to delete a task.
* @param tasks A list of tasks from which a task will be deleted.
public static void handleDelete(String userCommand, List<Task> tasks) {
throw new DukeException("invalid delete command (this task number does not exist)");
* Handles the marking of a task as completed based on the user command.
* @param userCommand The command given by the user to mark a task as completed.
* @param tasks A list of tasks from which a specific task will be marked as completed.
public static void handleMark(String userCommand, List<Task> tasks) {
throw new DukeException("invalid mark command (task number does not exist)");
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* Handles the unmarking of a task, reverting its status to not completed based on the user command.
* @param userCommand The command given by the user to unmark a task.
* @param tasks A list of tasks from which a specific task will be unmarked.
public static void handleUnmark(String userCommand, List<Task> tasks) {
throw new DukeException("invalid mark command (task number does not exist)");
System.out.println("Okay. I see you haven't done this task yet");
* Initialises and displays the welcome message for the Duke application.
" What can I do for you?\n" +
* Adds a "todo" task to the task list and provides user feedback.
* @param userCommand The user input command string.
* @param tasks The current list of tasks.
public static void handleTodo(String userCommand, List<Task> tasks) {
System.out.println("Got it I have added this task:" + "\n" +  currTask);
* Adds a "deadline" task to the task list and provides user feedback.
* @param userCommand The user input command string.
* @param tasks The current list of tasks.
public static void handleDeadline(String userCommand, List<Task> tasks) {
System.out.println("Got it I have added this task:" + "\n" +  currTask);
* Adds an "event" task to the task list and provides user feedback.
* @param userCommand The user input command string.
* @param tasks The current list of tasks.
public static void handleEvent(String userCommand, List<Task> tasks) {
Task currTask = new Events(description, fromDate, byDate);
System.out.println("Got it I have added this task:" + "\n" +  currTask);
* Closes the scanner and sends a bye message to the user.
* @param scanner The scanner used for user input.
System.out.println(" Bye. Come talk to Blob again soon!");
* Represents a custom exception for Duke application.
* This exception is thrown when Duke-specific conditions are violated.
* Constructs a new DukeException with the specified message.
* Represents an event task with a specified start and end date.
* An Events object is described by a description, start date, and end date.
* Initializes a new instance of the Events class with the given description, start date, and end date.
* @param startDate Start date of the event.
* @param endDate End date of the event.
* @throws DukeException if the provided description, start date, or end date is null or empty.
public Events(String description, String startDate, String endDate) throws DukeException {
throw new DukeException("description of event cannot be empty");
throw new DukeException("start date of event cannot be empty");
throw new DukeException("end date of event cannot be empty");
* Retrieves the start date of the event.
* Retrieves the end date of the event.
* Gets the type of the task.
* @return A string indicating the type of the task.
* Gets a formatted string representation of the Events task.
* @return A string representing the Events task.
return taskType + completed + this.getDescription() + "(" + fromMessage + " " + toMessage + ")";
* Represents a general task with a description and completion status.
* Creates a new task with a given description.
this.completed = false;  // Tasks are uncompleted by default
* Checks if the task is completed.
* Toggles the completion status of the task.
* Provides a type identifier for the task.
* Since this is a general task, it returns an empty string.
* Offers a formatted string showing the task's type, completion status, and description.
* Represents a ToDo task without a specific deadline or event date.
* A ToDo task is represented by a description.
* Creates a new ToDo task with the given description.
* @param description The description of ToDo task.
* @throws DukeException If the description is null or empty.
throw new DukeException("OOPS! The description of ToDo cannot be empty!");
* Indicates that this task is of type "T".
* @return The string "T" representing a ToDo task.
